results:
Based on the search results, I can provide you with comprehensive information about eternal winter symbolism in Narnia and its connections to spiritual themes:

## Eternal Winter Symbolism in Narnia

In C.S. Lewis's Chronicles of Narnia, winter is used as a symbol of the evil reign of the White Witch. The land of Narnia is plunged into an eternal winter, with no sign of spring or summer. This represents the oppressive and tyrannical rule of the White Witch, who seeks to maintain her power by keeping Narnia in a perpetual state of darkness and cold.(no content)The Witch imposes an enchanted, eternal winter on Narnia, symbolizing a dead, stagnant time. Nothing grows, animals hibernate, and people crouch around fires rather than enjoying the outdoors.

## Spiritual Meanings of the Winter

The eternal winter carries deep spiritual symbolism:

**Death and Stagnation**: Winter is Death. Cold. The opposition of Life.(no content)The spring is just as enchanted as the winter, only now Narnia is experiencing the epitome of life rather than death.

**Spiritual Oppression**: She opposes the lion Aslan and all that is good, and has cast a spell on Narnia so that it is always winter but never Christmas... Narnia was that land - a world that was in slavery to the curse of the White Witch, a world that was not as it should be and a world that was awaiting restoration.

**Absence of Hope**: And she has made a magic so that it is always winter in Narnia—always winter, but it never gets to Christmas... On any reading, the White Witch is a symbol for Satan in Lewis' allegory.

## The Hundred Year Winter's Impact

As a curse upon her conquered Narnian subjects, she began the Long Winter, magically forcing the entire land into a state of frozen snow and ice, which lasted throughout her entire reign of one hundred years... She immediately put her centuries of magical study to work, fabricating a perpetual climate of snow and ice throughout the Kingdom, which not only oppressed the Narnian citizens, but also ensured that no more silver apple trees could be grown. During the one hundred years of Jadis's reign, the seasons of spring, summer and autumn were extinct during this Long Winter.

## Spiritual Transformation: Winter to Spring

Winter to spring = death to life, i.e. resurrection.(no content)Of course, Christmas occurs before spring can come, because Christmas is the birth of Christ. It is Christmas that signals hope for mankind: with the birth of Christ, we are given the hope of new life. Spring follows Christmas and all of a sudden the woods are completely alive—flowers are blooming, springs and brooks are chuckling, birds are singing, and delightful smells waft past on gentle breezes.

The search results don't contain specific information about Polish winters or historical occupation connections to Narnia's symbolism. The winter symbolism in Narnia appears to focus primarily on universal spiritual themes of oppression, death, stagnation, and the eventual triumph of good over evil through resurrection and renewal.
